awd_titl_txt: LEAPS-MPS: Uncovering and Exploiting Multiscale Structures in Big Data Using Diffusion-Based Representation and Optimal Sampling
awd_abstract_narration:
Consumers of information desire efficient methods for processing data, and scientists are interested in understanding patterns and structures in data to explain why various phenomena occur. The focus of emerging big data analytics research has shifted to alternative data structures, especially (combinatorial) graphs, and networks. Although graphs and networks require mathematically complex algorithms, they have built-in links that highlight important relationships between nodes and make them simpler to interpret in applications. This project introduces new theories and algorithms to address aspects of graph data challenges that have impacts on diverse segments of society including imaging tools used by medical professionals to diagnose and treat diseases, and on applications ranging from the regulatory networks describing the interactions between genes, RNA, and proteins in the brain, to hardware and sensor technology. The methods explored expand the family of harmonic analysis algorithms that produced tools such as the wavelet-based ones for images used in commercial applications and sampling theorems for telegraph communication. The project also involves training and mentoring undergraduate students, particularly students from underrepresented groups with less exposure to careers in science and technology. The intent is to motivate and prepare them for careers in advanced mathematical sciences and increase the global competitiveness of the US-based STEM workforce. Other activities include promoting equity and inclusion in STEM fields through public lectures and coordinated outreach activities.
 
Applied harmonic analysis tools will play a central role in the two-year project. The primary research objectives include: (i) enhancing the quality of multiscale representations of data signals on graphs and networks, (ii) the optimization of sampling strategies for high-dimensional, non-bandlimited signals, and (iii) the design of compression algorithms to demonstrate the potential for datasets on graphs. The analysis combines frame theory, diffusion geometry, and directional multiscale modeling; novel numerical techniques will be developed using numerical linear algebra and computational harmonic analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2021, the PI was awarded an NSF grant for the project "Uncovering and Exploiting Multiscale Structures in Big Data Using Diffusion-Based Representation and Optimal Sampling." The PI successfully met the project's primary objectives, which included advancing diffusion-based data representations and developing optimal sampling strategies for high-dimensional data. These accomplishments have already resulted in significant outcomes, such as new algorithms and publications, and are expected to generate additional research products and collaborative opportunities in the future. 

The grant's primary research objectives were to: 1) enhance multiscale representations of data signals on graphs and networks, including the development of compression algorithms, and 2) optimize sampling strategies for high-dimensional, non-bandlimited signals. Both objectives were successfully achieved.

Building on preliminary results from iterative sampling algorithms, the PI revisited Shannon's theorem for a representative class of signals to explore its implications for big data. This work, conducted in collaboration with a colleague, resulted in a published paper.

In graph representation research, the PI and another collaborator developed a novel set of graph Laplacian-based signatures to classify large datasets. These signatures are complemented by computational algorithms that incorporate recent advances in graph neural networks, extending the landscape of diffusion maps and heat kernel signatures. A publication on this work is forthcoming.

The PI also explored tensor structures for the latter project, which sparked joint efforts in randomized iterative methods for tensor regression under the t-product. This additional research, beyond the scope of the original grant, has already resulted in one publication, with several more anticipated.

The PI's research outcomes have advanced theories and algorithms that address critical data challenges. These contributions have broad societal implications, including potential applications in medical imaging tools that help diagnose and treat diseases.

This work has been conducted in collaboration with Ambrose Yim, Christina Frederick, Alejandra Castillo, Jamie Haddock, Iryna Hartsock, Paulina Hoyos, Lara Kassab, Alona Kryshchenko, Kamila Larripa, Deanna Needell, and Shambhavi Suryanarayanan.

The PI expanded her mentoring efforts by supervising six undergraduate research assistants over three years, including two from Amherst College and four from Wellesley College. These research assistants gained exposure to advanced concepts in applied harmonic analysis and machine learning, along with intensive programming practice. To broaden their professional networks, the PI facilitated interactions with guest speakers--primarily from underrepresented groups--invited to the department colloquium. As a result of this mentorship, two research assistants are now applying to graduate programs in mathematical sciences. In June 2024, the PI also served as a research mentor in a week-long AMS MRC on Mathematics of Adversarial, Interpretable, and Explainable AI.

Beyond mentoring, the PI integrated research activities into teaching and course development, enriching the curriculum with cutting-edge STEM topics. These efforts have not only advanced the careers of minoritized students in mathematics but also contributed to diversifying and strengthening the US-based STEM workforce.

The PI has shared her ongoing research through plenary talks and named lectures (e.g., the 2023 WIMIN at Smith and the 2024 Runnals Dinner at Colby) as well as at international conferences, such as ICIAM 2023 in Tokyo.
